p.s: The novel and especially the film, had a very big impact on my perspective.
For me it was very interesting to see the experience and life of a black girl on a school, where most of the people are white.
One very interesting thing was to learn about the two different versions of Starr, Williamson-Starr and the real Starr.
I was very sad, because you had to see, how Starr shows no personality in school and has to hide the real Starr.
For me the movie in general, was very emotional, especially the scene, where Khalil died, who was young and innocent.
It also refrechedrefreshed the whole Black Lives Matter thing and gave me the impression that I was part of it.
I was also very impressed and inspired by StarrsStarr's father, who didn't want to move, but make their city better.
The final scene of the movie was the sadest and scariest for me.
It was the scene, where StarrsStarr's younger brother pointed a gun on him.
With this scene, the sentence Thug Life or The Hate U Give Little Infants Fucks Everybody became very important for me.
It showed me that in the cities, where many black people live and police violance is a thing, also the yougestyoungest people will be affected.
